availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Benjamin Mayberry Prentiss (Quincy, Illinois, merchant, attorney, and soldier)

body.p: Quincy, Illinois, merchant, attorney, and soldier. Belleville, Virginia, native. Married to Margaret A. Prentiss. Father of Harrison T. Prentiss, Guy C. A. Prentiss, Martha R. Prentiss, Jacob H. Prentiss, Ella Prentiss, Benjamin M. Prentiss, Jr., Clay Prentiss, and Joseph Prentiss. Moved to Marion County, Missouri, in 1836. Worked at a rope-walk from 1836 to 1841. Relocated to Quincy. Veteran of the Mexican-American War. Returned to Quincy. Worked as a rope-maker in 1850. Candidate for the House of Representatives of the United States on the Republican ticket in 1860. Forwarding merchant in Quincy in 1860. Served in the 10th Illinois Volunteer Infantry Regiment as colonel from April 1861 to August 1861. Served as brigadier general of volunteers in the U.S. Army in August 1861, effective from May 1861. Comanded troops in Missouri and Tennessee. Captured at the Battle of Shiloh on April 6, 1862 and exchanged in October 1862. Promoted to major general on March 13, 1863, effective from November 1862. Commanded the Easter District of Arkansas at Helena, Arkansas, from March 1863 to October 1863. Resigned from the U.S. Army in October 1863 and returned to Quincy to practice law.

ab.bibl:
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Illinois, Adams, Quincy North Ward, p. 201A.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Illinois, Adams, Quincy 1st Ward, p. 10.
Ninth Manuscript Census of the United States (1870), Population Schedules, Illinois, Adams, Quincy 6th Ward, p. 62.
Ezra Warner, Generals in Blue:Lives of the Union Commanders (Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1964), 168, 385-386.
Find A Grave, "Benjamin Mayberry Prentiss" (1819-1901)," Memorial #5896672, https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/5896672/benjamin-mayberry-prentiss (accessed April 2, 2018).
